Agreed. I have several problems with the way the Terri Schiavo case was handled.
 
 1. Michael should not have been her guardian. Normally the spouse is a good default option, but any sentient adult knows of cases where it would be a bad idea. Would he be the guardian if the couple had filed for divorce, even though the divorce was not yet final? I think not. Once Michael moved on with his life, moving in with his girlfriend and starting a family with her, there is not a court in the country that would deny Terri a divorce. But Judge Greer made sure there was no one to speak for her.
 
 2. The question of Terri's wishes was decided on hearsay evidence so flimsy that it would not convict anyone of jaywalking, much less the death penalty. Michael and two of his family said Terri would wish to die under the circumstances; Terri's family produced sworn affadavits from friends of Terri that Michael had several times stated during the first few years (before the malpractice settlement money came through) that he (Michael) had no idea what Terri would have wanted.
 
 3. Terri's execution was brutal, cruel, and inhumane. Her mother was denied any opportunity to comfort her dying daughter with water to wet her lips or provide a sliver of ice for her swollen tongue -- was the judge afraid Terri might choke to death? I certainly wouldn't want to be executed that way, and would much prefer the kinder and gentler hot shot.
 
 I agree with the sentiments of one of the disabled person groups: Don't pull the plug until I am (a) terminal, (b) in great pain, and (c) no one wants to come visit me.
